title: Second person convicted of murder of Sheffield man who suffered 117 separate injuries
text:
A second person has been found guilty of the murder of a Sheffield man who sustained more than 100 separate injuries.
Alison Sarah Moss, 46, of Fox Walk, Walkley, denied being involved in the murder of Craig Wild at her home but was found guilty by a jury at Sheffield Crown Court today.
It comes after her partner David Michael Webster, of Leppings Lane, Hillsborough, pleaded guilty to murder at an earlier hearing.
Mr Wild's body was found under a blood-stained duvet in Moss' living room in August.
He had been attacked with weapons including two knives and a screwdriver, and had also been punched and kicked.
The court heard how Moss and Webster had been drinking and taking drugs at the house before they were joined by Mr Wild and an argument erupted.
Webster knew exactly what he was doing, from the second he struck Mr Wild with the knife.
From that point onwards, his intention was to kill him. He admitted this stating that it was his full intention.
He is a dangerous man who has not only shown absolutely no remorse for his actions but has appeared proud of what he has done.
Moss denied any involvement but the forensic evidence found on shoes and clothing proved that she had participated in this brutal murder. We gathered CCTV evidence to show the clothing she had been wearing prior to the attack. Moss changed her clothing and shoes before the police could gain access to the flat.
Together the pair attempted to hide what had happened when officers attended the address. They are both extremely violent individuals who have murdered a defenceless man without any provocation.
– Detective Chief Inspector Dave Stopford, South Yorkshire Police Craig Wild. Credit: South Yorkshire Police Webster and Moss will be sentenced for the murder tomorrow.
Moss will also be sentenced for assaulting a 17-year-old man with a cut throat razor last month.
The impact our dearest Craig’s death has had on our family is one of total devastation for all of us who loved him so dearly.
As Alison Moss pleaded not guilty we have had to go through the harrowing process of a trial. It’s been too much for most of us to attend and hear the shocking details of the way that Craig was killed.
The guilty verdict of Alison Moss today goes some way towards helping us as a family to come together and try to come to terms with his death, knowing that the people who were responsible will be brought to justice.
– Statement from the family of Craig Wild Sheffield South Yorkshire
